title: The Hawaiian story of the wind keepers - Sydney Iaukea

multiple-choice.question: Who is the Hawaiian wind goddess mentioned in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: Paka'a

options.label: B
options.text: La'amaomao

options.label: C
options.text: Kuapaka'a

options.label: D
options.text: Keawenuia'umi

multiple-choice.question: What object housed the winds of the Islands and was passed down to Paka'a?

options.label: A
options.text: A sacred spear

options.label: B
options.text: A gourd

options.label: C
options.text: A canoe

options.label: D
options.text: A crown

multiple-choice.question: Why were the two navigators envious of Paka'a?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was a skilled sailor

options.label: B
options.text: Because he was the king's most trusted attendant

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was wealthy

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was a skilled warrior

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the king's navigators dismissing Kuapaka'a's warning about the storm?

options.label: A
options.text: The storm passed quickly

options.label: B
options.text: The king's fleet was able to sail safely

options.label: C
options.text: The king's fleet was forced to shelter on Moloka'i

options.label: D
options.text: Kuapaka'a was punished

multiple-choice.question: How did Kuapaka'a ultimately get revenge on the two navigators who wronged his father?

options.label: A
options.text: He challenged them to a duel

options.label: B
options.text: He called the winds and caused them to fall overboard

options.label: C
options.text: He poisoned their food

options.label: D
options.text: He stole their canoes

multiple-choice.question: What was the wager in the canoe race between Kuapaka'a and the eight fishermen?

options.label: A
options.text: A catch of flying fish against a basket of fruit

options.label: B
options.text: A canoe against a plot of land

options.label: C
options.text: Kuapaka'a's bones against the bones of the fishermen

options.label: D
options.text: A: A catch of flying fish against that of the fishermen, and later, Kuapaka'a's bones against the bones of the fishermen

multiple-choice.question: Why did Kuapaka'a initially keep his identity a secret from the king?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was afraid of the king's reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to test the king's loyalty and dedication

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was trying to deceive the king

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was trying to protect his father

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the king's realization that he had been deceived by the two navigators?

options.label: A
options.text: He became even more trusting of the navigators

options.label: B
options.text: He banished Paka'a from the kingdom

options.label: C
options.text: He longed for Paka'a and wanted to make amends

options.label: D
options.text: He went to war with a neighboring kingdom

multiple-choice.question: How did Kuapaka'a prove his skills to the king and earn his trust?

options.label: A
options.text: By winning a battle against a rival kingdom

options.label: B
options.text: By navigating the king's canoe through treacherous waters

options.label: C
options.text: By maintaining a storm for four months and then clearing the sky

options.label: D
options.text: By providing the king with a bountiful harvest

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate outcome for Paka'a and the king?

options.label: A
options.text: Paka'a was banished from the kingdom forever

options.label: B
options.text: The king and Paka'a became enemies

options.label: C
options.text: The king and Paka'a were reunited, and Paka'a's lands and position were restored

options.label: D
options.text: Paka'a became the new king
